awd_titl_txt: RUI Collaborative Research: Niche evolution, ecological limits, and the macroecology of land plant biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of the long-term evolution of plant species diversity is important to understanding current losses or maintenance of diversity as habitats shift and become fragmented.  This project will examine how diversity has evolved in the western hemisphere using a database of over 100,000 plant species.  Using new approaches in informatics applied to genetic, geographical and environmental data, the project will investigate the possible causes of shifts in species diversity at extensive geographic scales by considering evolutionary diversification, dispersal, adaptation, and coexistence.  Additionally, the project will determine if hard limits on species diversity exist and the extent to which these are determined by environmental history.  This is a "Big Data" project that will simultaneously develop tools in informatics and train students on the use of these statistical tools.  The tools will be made widely available, and training will build on the collaboration among those at a liberal arts college, a comprehensive master's institution, and a research university.

This research project will contribute to a predictive science of biodiversity based on underlying ecological and evolutionary processes. The Botanical Information and Ecology Network will be leveraged to test explanations for assembly of diverse biomes over evolutionary time by taking advantage of recent advances in biodiversity informatics, phylogenetic analysis, and the modeling of multivariate niche hypervolumes.  How the evolutionary contingencies of adaptation, diversification, and dispersal interact with possible ecological limits on the niche space of different environments will be investigated.  The taxonomic, functional, and phylogenetic diversity of whole biomes and clades will be quantified in order to model niche evolution and biome shifts at extensive geographic and temporal scales.  Whether evolutionary biome shifts are systematically associated with changes in functional traits or niche hypervolumes will be examined.  Whether or not the functional niche space of biomes becomes saturated over evolutionary time, and if saturation reflects ecological limits on diversification through physiology, will be tested. The research will contribute novel answers to some of the most persistent questions in ecology, evolution, and biogeography, as well as innovative new tools in ecoinformatics.

por.por_cntn:
Ecologists and biogeographers have long known that the biodiversity of plants, like that of most other organisms, is strongly correlated with climate, with the diversity of species peaking in warm, moist tropical forests and falling as you venture into colder and drier climates of the temperate and polar regions. But while the pattern has long been understood, it has proven difficult to disentangle the many ecological and evolutionary processes that have produced this prominent feature of life on Earth. This project approaches this problem by leveraging one of the largest botanical biodiversity databases yet produced, detailing the geography, ecological characteristics, and evolutionary relationships of over 100,000 plant species across all of North and South America.

Using new statistical and computational approaches developed for the project, we compared biodiversity across tropical, temperate, and polar biomes, that is, climatically defined vegetation zones characterized by different sorts of dominant plants, such as moist tropical forests, temperate grasslands, or tundra. In making these comparisons, we examined not only the diversity of species present in different regions, but also the variety of ecological and physiological characteristics represented by those species (functional diversity) and the number of different evolutionary lineages that they belong to (evolutionary diversity).

In examining functional diversity, we initially found that despite large differences in species diversity, both tropical and temperate biomes showed similar levels of functional diversity despite big differences in climate. However, looking more closely, we found an intriguing and previously undocumented pattern: the most functionally distinctive species in any biome tended to be uncommon and restricted in their distribution, whereas the most common and widespread species in that biome all tended to be functionally similar. When we focused on only these widespread and functionally representative species, biomes were more distinguishable and patterns among the biomes reflected a clearer correspondence between climate and functional diversity. Thus, while plants may take on a wide range of characteristics in any biome, particular sets of characteristics, are associated with being widespread and common under different climate conditions.

Our studies of phylogenetic diversity examined how the extreme challenges of drought and freezing influenced evolutionary diversity. We found that evolutionary diversity of plants in temperate dry biomes is even lower than in biomes subject to drought or freezing alone. We further showed that, in contrast to simple species diversity, evolutionary diversity in some temperate forest regions is comparable to or even higher than that of some tropical moist forests, suggesting that some temperate biomes have accumulated angiosperm lineages over very deep evolutionary timescales.

Together, our results suggest that climate impacts biodiversity both ecologically, by constraining the sets of characteristics that allow species to become widespread under different conditions, and evolutionarily, by imposing ecological and physiological challenges that can only be overcome by lineages able to adapt to climatic extremes. Our results also have important implications for understanding how biodiversity and ecosystem functions and services will respond to climate change. We show that evolutionarily novel and extreme climatic conditions place substantial limits on both evolutionary and functional biodiversity. The ongoing warming of temperate and polar environments, and the expansion of arid environments in both tropical and temperate regions is likely to contribute to global losses in evolutionary and functional diversity of plants, which underlie the delivery of many critically important ecosystem services.

This project could only be completed by applying computationally intensive data science approaches to compile, manipulate, and analyze biodiversity data collected by countless botanists, ecologists, and biogeographers over many lifetimes. The age of Big Data provides tremendous opportunities for understanding the ecology and evolution of Earth’s biosphere and anticipating the response of biodiversity to rapid, human-induced climate change. But the next generation of scientists can only take advantage of this opportunity if they have the research tools to draw informative patterns out of the daunting mass of measurements. Our project provided students with the training necessary to work with complex, large-scale data at multiple levels in the undergraduate curriculum. We incorporated data science approaches into undergraduate courses at multiple levels and developed course-based and independent research projects that allowed student researchers to address original questions using their newly acquired tools. The project also provided training for a postdoctoral scientist, who became a productive undergraduate teacher and helped to found a research coordination network dedicated to empowering undergraduate instructors in ecology to incorporate data science into their own curricula. Moreover, the training we provided in computational data science benefited not only those participants who continued in their studies of biodiversity. Work on the project advanced the careers of both postdoctoral and undergraduate researchers, leading to graduate studies or employment in epidemiological modeling, data science, ecology, electrical engineering, environmental education, environmental policy, medicine, and neuroscience.
